concept.dc:description: Organisms occuring in an area because they were introduced for the purpose of biological control of another organism.
concept.comments: Released intentionally into the (semi)natural environment with the purpose of controlling the population(s) of one or more organisms. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms introduced for the purpose of erosion control/dune stabilization (windbreaks, hedges, etc.).
concept.comments: Probably only applicable to plants. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Fish stocked into the wild either to create a fishery or for recreational angling.
concept.comments: Largely applicable to freshwater and anadromous fish. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Animals stocked into the wild specifically with the intention that they would be hunted for sport.
concept.comments: Largely applicable to terrestrial vertebrates. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Landscape/flora/fauna "improvement" in the wild.
concept.comments: "Improvement" in this context is intended for introductions for the purpose of aesthetic enhancement of the landscape, as opposed to practical introductions for the purpose of erosion control, agriculture, forestry etc. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms introduced for conservation purposes or wildlife management.
concept.comments: The organism was released with the intention of improving the conservation status of the species or the conservation status other species in the habitat. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: ochrana přírody nebo správa volně žijících živočichů
conservación o manejo de vida silvestre
conservation ou gestion de la vie sauvage

concept.dc:description: Release in nature for use (other than above, e.g., fur, transport, medical use).
concept.comments: This term refers to organisms intentionally and directly released into the wild to serve a specific purpose. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: A catch-all term for intentional releases not for human use that are not covered by other more specific terms.
concept.comments: Compare with "other escape from confinement". See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Plants grown with the intention of harvesting.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: agriculture (y compris les matières premières des biocarburants)

concept.dc:description: The analog of agriculture and farmed animals, specifically related to aquatic organisms.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms in public collections of plants and/or animals.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: jardin botanique/zoo/aquarium (à l'exclusion des aquariums domestiques)

concept.dc:description: Privately kept animals.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: pet/aquarium/terrarium species (including live food for such species)
druhy v zájmovém chovu/akváriích/teráriích (včetně živé potravy pro tyto druhy)
especies mascota/de acuario/de terrario (incluyendo comida viva para esas especies)
plantes ornementales, animaux de compagnie, organismes d’aquarium ainsi que leurs aliments vivants

concept.dc:description: Animals cared for and bred with the specific intention of using their products, such as meat and milk.
concept.comments: Farmed animals are generally kept in a defined area, such as a fields. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: farmed animals (including animals left under limited control)
hospodářská zvířata (včetně zvířat ponechaných pod omezenou kontrolou)
animales de granja (incluyendo animales dejados bajo control limitado)
animaux d'élevage (y compris les animaux laissés sous contrôle limité)

concept.dc:description: Trees specifically introduced to provide timber and other forestry products.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms escaped from a fur farm, including unauthorised releases.
concept.comments: Probably only applicable to vertebrates raised for their pelts and skins. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Plants distributed by the ornamental and decorative plants industry.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Ornamental plants introduced through pathways other than the horticultural industry.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: con fin ornamental distinto a horticultura

concept.dc:description: Plants and animals introduced for the purpose of breeding or scientific and medical research, including science education.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: 연구 및 현지 외 교배(시설 내)

concept.dc:description: Live food imported for human consumption or live bait, such as shellfish and snails.
concept.comments: Live food, such as mealworms, for the organisms kept as pets should be classified under the pet term. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms brought into an area with the intention of keeping them in captivity permanently, but that have subsequently escaped.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms transported into an area together with plant material.
concept.comments: These may be other plants, diseases, fungi and animals. They may be attached to the plant or within the soil. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Contaminants, pathogens and parasites transported with live, frozen or preserved bait used to catch fish or other organisms.
concept.comments: Typical examples include crustaceans, cephalopods and molluscs. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Foods for human consumption, whether they are transported live or dead.
concept.comments: This term includes unintentional introduction of contaminants such as diseases on those foods and in the case of plants, should include seeds. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: contamination alimentaire (y compris de la nourriture vivante)

concept.dc:description: Contaminants carried either on or in the body of transported animals.
concept.comments: Transported animals carry other organisms in their coats, in their guts and in soil on their hooves and feet. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: contaminant on animals (except parasites, organisms transported by host/vector)
kontaminant na zvířatech (kromě parazitů, organismů přenášených hostitelem/vektorem)
contaminante de animales (excepto parásitos, organismos transportados por hospedador/vector)
contamination des animaux (sauf les parasites et les organismes transportés par un hôte/vecteur)

concept.dc:description: Parasitic and pathogenic organisms transported with their host or vector animal.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: parasites on animals (including organisms transported by host and vector)
parazité na zvířatech (včetně organismů přenášených hostitelem a přenašečem)
parásitos de animales (incluyendo organismos transportados por hospedador y vector)
parasites d'animaux (y compris les organismes transportés par un hôte/vecteur)

concept.dc:description: Organisms transported on plant material.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: contaminant on plants (except parasites, species transported by host/vector)
kontaminant na rostlinách (kromě parazitů, druhů přenášených hostitelem/vektorem)
contaminante de plantas (excepto parásitos, especies transportadas por hospedador/vector)
contaminateur de végétaux (sauf les parasites et les organismes transportés par un hôte/vecteur)
식물틀 통한 오염물질(기생동물, 숙주를 통해 옮겨진 종 제외)

concept.dc:description: Parasitic and pathogenic organisms transported with their host or vector plant.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: parasites on plants (including species transported by host and vector)
parazité na rostlinách (včetně druhů přenášených hostitelem a přenašečem)
parásitos de plantas (incluyendo especies transportadas por hospedador y vector)
parasites de végétaux (y compris les organismes transportés par un hôte/vecteur)

concept.dc:description: Organisms contaminating transported seeds.
concept.comments: These may be parasites or pathogens of seeds or species that eat seeds, whether intended to be transported or not. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Contaminants on unprocessed timber, processed wood and wood-derived products.
concept.comments: Examples include wooden furniture, saw dust and fire wood. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms transported with their habitat material to a new location.
concept.comments: Examples include materials such as soil, vegetation, straw and wood chips. Unless these materials are sterilised the organisms can be transported with their habitat to a new location. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: transportation of habitat material (soil, vegetation, wood etc)
přeprava materiálu stanoviště (půda, vegetace, dřevo atd.)
transporte de material del hábitat (suelo, vegetación, madera, etc.)
transport des matériaux de l'habitat (terre, végétation, bois, etc.)

concept.dc:description: Aquatic organisms moved between sites on equipment of recreational anglers and professional fishermen.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: équipement de pêche/pêche à la ligne

concept.dc:description: Stowaways transported in or on cargo containers or bulk cargo units.
concept.comments: The difference between this category and others, such as "hitchhikers on ship/boat", is that the organism embarked and disembarked from the container rather than the ship. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms that enter airplanes or other aircraft, such as helicopters, and are transported by them to another location.
concept.comments: This term does not apply to organisms that embarked in containers that were subsequently loaded onto an aircraft. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: černí pasažéři v letadle nebo na palubě letadla
autostopista sobre o dentro de aeronave
passager clandestin sur ou dans un avion

concept.dc:description: Organisms that enter directly onto boats or ships and are transported by them to another location.
concept.comments: This term does not apply to organisms that embarked in containers that are subsequently loaded onto the ship, nor to contaminants of products loaded onto the ship. The term is intended for organisms that directly interact with the boat or ship. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: hitchhikers on ship/boat (excluding ballast water and hull fouling)
černí pasažéři na lodi/člunu (kromě balastní vody a znečištění trupu)
autostopista sobre embarcación (excluyendo agua de lastre y organismos adheridos al casco)
passager clandestin sur un navire/bateau (à l'exclusion des eaux de ballast et de la contamination de la coque)

concept.dc:description: Organisms carried on the surfaces of or within heavy machinery and equipment.
concept.comments: This includes military equipment, farm machinery and manufacturing equipment. This term does not include products carried by vehicles. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms transported on people and/or their personal luggage.
concept.comments: Examples include organisms transported by tourists. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: people and their luggage/equipment (in particular tourism)
lidé a jejich zavazadla/vybavení (zejména v cestovním ruchu)
personas y su equipaje/equipamiento (en particular turismo)
personnes et leurs bagages/équipements (en particulier les touristes)

concept.dc:description: Organic material, particularly unprocessed plant material that is used to pack transported goods.
concept.comments: Examples include woodern pallets, boxes, bags and baskets. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: organic packing material, in particular wood packaging
organický obalový materiál, zejména dřevěné obaly
material orgánico de embalaje, en particular embalaje de madera
matériau d'emballage organique, notamment en bois

concept.dc:description: Organisms transported within the water pumped into boats and ships to provide ballast.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms that attach themselves to the subsurface hull of boats and ships.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: organismos adheridos a casco de embarcación

concept.dc:description: Other vehicle hitchhikers that have been unintentionally dispersed, but are not covered by other terms.
concept.comments: These organisms may be carried on or within the vehicle. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: A catch-all term for any transport related dispersal that is not covered in other terms.
concept.comments: Examples include fouling from offshore oil and gas platforms, offshore renewable energy sites (such as wind farms, pipelines, cable transport, etc.) See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms that dispersed through artificial waterways created to connect previosuly unconnected water bodies.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Unintentional dispersal by organisms using artificial tunnels, bridges, roads and railways.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Dispersal of organisms to new regions by natural dispersal from regions in which they are alien.
concept.comments: These are alien species that have previously been introduced through one of these pathways: release in nature, escape from confinement, transport-contaminant, transport-stowaway, or corridor. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

term.dc:title: natural dispersal across borders of invasive alien organisms
přirozené šíření invazních cizích organismů přes hranice
dispersión natural a través de fronteras de organismos exóticos invasores
dispersion naturelle d'organismes exotiques envahissants à travers les frontières

concept.dc:description: Organisms transported and released by humans in a (semi)natural environment with the intention that they should live there without further human aid.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms intentionally transported by humans and intended to be kept in captivity or cultivation, but having inadvertently escaped from human control.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: An umbrella term for all species transported as contaminants in other products.
concept.comments: An alien species is a contaminant if it had a trophic or biotic relationship to organisms or items being transported and was to some extent dependent on them for survival. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: An umbrella term for all species transported by riding on forms of transport where the organism has a direct interaction with the transport and is not merely carried as part of, or a contaminant of cargo.
concept.comments: A stowaway has no trophic or biotic relationship to the organisms or items being transported. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Infrastructure, such as bridges, tunnels and canals have removed natural barriers to dispersal and allowed a species to move into a novel location.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms that spread by natural dispersal, without action or assistance by humans, from regions in which they are also alien.
concept.comments: The term refers to secondary dispersal from an area where the taxon is also alien. See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms were brought to new area with the specific intention of keeping them alive in the new region, regardless of whether they were intended to be cultivated or released into the wild.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: The organism was unintentionally brought to a new region.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129

concept.dc:description: Organisms dispersed naturally, even if that dispersal was aided by changes in the landscape created by humans.
concept.comments: See also Harrower et al. 2017. http://nora.nerc.ac.uk/id/eprint/519129
